In Para, 2:

"...by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said the oil flow could grow from the current estimate of 5,000 barrels a day to 10 times that much, which could be 2.1 million gallons a day. "

Eh? There is either a math mistake or a typo here. 10 x 5,000 = 50,000, which is still more than a factor of magnitude less than 2.1 million...

Will outraged people speak with their wallets, stop buying BP gas, and put them out of business? Or will it be out-of-mind and business as usual as soon as the next news cycle begins?

If the consumer(s) can't or won't regulate businesses by buying from responsible companies and avoiding irresponsible/damaging companies, which would effectively keep government out of such affairs, why should those same people have a say when government does fill the need for regualtion?

Also, why are taxpayers paying for any of this cleanup? If BP makes the profit during good times, they should take the loss in paying for the *entire* cleanup effort, no matter how long it takes.

Have we heard this before? Have we been told before it can never happen, trust us we have systems in place etc?

We have a federal government that after so many years of Republican presidents has been conditioned to being lead by the nose by the corporations the fed is supposed to be regulating. No concern is too big or important for the federal govt. to waive if it means it might cost or inconvenience a corporation. In this case it meant not demanding that rigs have extra emergency valves, because Oil companies complained it would cost them more money....

The next fiasco will involve nuclear power. Instead of an oil plume heading for the coast we will be faced with a radioactive cloud heading for either coast after a nuclear reactor implodes. Maybe that will get the attention of the Republicans who prefer their government regulation weak to non existent.

BP continues to dispute the NOAA estimate that 5k barrels per day is leaking, they claimed that their ridiculously low estimates of 1k is correct, the feds challenged them the same day, but you fault the feds for underestimating the size of the spill, and BP claimed one year ago that this could not happen, we have "modern technology", federal regulation of offshore oil-drilling is not necessary, BP is already trying to establish its' defense for the civil trial, and where is sarah "drill baby drill" palin now, perhaps we should amend that to "drill, baby sperm whale, drill"...
additionally, you change the scale of your reporting of this disaster from gallons to barrels without any concern for understanding and consistency, for instance "the oil flow could grow from the current estimate of 5,000 barrels a day to 10 times that much, which could be 2.1 million gallons a day", from 5k to 2.5 m!!!...
securing the source of the leak is a vital question, in that BP and the other oil drilling corporations have argued that they know what they are doing and that they use the bust available technology, but clearly here they did not know what they were doing and do not have the ability to shut down this environmental disaster...

When it comes to oil, America is a sick society.

We will go to wars for oil.

We will be ready to destroy the planet for the oil.

We need cars and electricity, for our pleasures.

We need oil to be cheap, must be less than three dollars per gallon.

Now the blame game, is it BP's fault or the fedral government?

Half baked technologies for profit are one day going to kill us and that day is closing on us soon.

Feckless George II removed the requirement for blow out capture in 2003, because the oil cartels said the 500k was too much. How much is this fiasco going to cost to clean up?
Drill baby drill.

Sarah Palin via facebook:
In the coming days, there will be hearings to discover the cause of the explosion and the subsequent leak. Actions will be taken to increase oversight to prevent future accidents. Government can and must play an appropriate role here. If a company was lax in its prevention practices, it must be held accountable. It is inexcusable for any oil company to not invest in preventative measures. They must be held accountable or the public will forever distrust the industry.

This was the position I took as an oil and gas regulator and as Governor of Alaska when my administration ramped up oversight of the oil industry and created a petroleum-systems-integrity office to monitor our oil and gas infrastructure for potential environmental risks. I took a lot of heat for the stand I took “against the oil industry” (which is how political adversaries labeled my actions). But we took tough action because there was proof of some improper maintenance of oil infrastructure which I believed was unacceptable. We instituted new oversight and held British Petroleum (BP) financially accountable for poor maintenance practices. We also filed a Friend-of-the-Court brief against Exxon’s interests for its decades-old responsibility to compensate Alaskans affected by the Valdez spill, and I took other actions “against” the industry which ultimately helped hold it accountable.

All responsible energy development must be accompanied by strict oversight, but even with the strictest oversight in the world, accidents still happen. No human endeavor is ever without risk – whether it’s sending a man to the moon or extracting the necessary resources to fuel our civilization. I repeat the slogan “drill here, drill now” not out of naiveté or disregard for the tragic consequences of oil spills – my family and my state and I know firsthand those consequences. How could I still believe in drilling America’s domestic supply of energy after having seen the devastation of the Exxon-Valdez spill? I continue to believe in it because increased domestic oil production will make us a more secure, prosperous, and peaceful nation.

More and more people are figuring out that our President, pleasant and well-meaning though he may be, is an idiot.
This has got to be a wake up call!
Too bad there isn't a spare concret cassion lying around that could be scuttled right on top of the spill.

This is a national tragedy that seems to be spiraling out of control. To think that the leak may not be stopped for 2 to 3 months is unbelievable. The Valdez had a finite amount of gas to leak while this well is gushing to gosh knows what.

Now, to make matter worse, there is a story breaking about a mistress for our President. PLEASE, let this not be true. I don't care for his policies, but gosh darnit, we don't need anyone in the WH who isn't focused entirely on this oil spill and all the other priorities facing the country! All of our elected men and women need to get to work!!!
I say let's quit trying to salvage the well and torpedo it. Forget sealing it.  Let the earth seal itself.  Then dump however many ships full of gravel or rocks it takes to bury it for good.

As a recent arrival in this city I am shocked at the apathy of local people to their situation.  The "haves" are too busy blaming their problems on the "have-nots".  Many of those "haves" are earning high salaries working for oil companies they don't want to acknowledge what their employers are doing to the environment.  They are happy to have things as they are, living for the moment.

It's a shame the Obama administration did nothing until the spill became so large, a major environmental disaster is now eminent.

If they can't handle an oil spill, what else can't they handle?
LAST ACCIDENT LIKE THIS IN THE GULF WAS 1979.  An accident every 31 years is pretty good safety record considering the complexity of the operation.

I grew up spending all our vacations on the Gulf Coast of Florida. It wasn't as tony as the east coast, but it was beautiful, wild and gorgeous. When I first arrived at Little Gasparilla Island almost 20 years ago there were Mantees in the harbor and Dolfins following our boats. The fish would jump out of the sea as you walked along the beaches. Over the years we had our issues with the red tides, horrible red algae choking oxygen off in the sea and giving off a horrible irritant to those breathing the air it created. The Manatees were seldom seen in the last few years, but the red tides were better since more pollution controls were in place. I haven't returned since my father died two years ago. His homes are sold now. I can't believe how much the world can change in just two short years. Anyone who does not understand the tragic magnitude of this event is living a very disconnected life. I don't find it surprising that Halliburton had a hand in this because the values of this company is corporate greed at all cost-- people, the ocean, the environment. How can we put a price on what has been lost? What kind of a world are we living in? What are we even living for, to destroy our planet, much as we do each other, and our own selves? It is all very disheartening. I at one time hoped to share the Island with my kids and their kids, but we haven't gone back since Dad's death. I guess it really is true. You can not go home again.

Officers of Enron and Worldcom went to prison for financial fraud, but they didn't kill anybody or destroy the Gulf Coast of the United States with their [criminal] negligence.  British Petroleum lied, either though ignorance that the English accent is typically used to hide or intentionally, about the seriousness of the situation saying, for a week, that it  was no big thing and they could handle it.

I see a couple of things going on here. 1) Now that there is a disaster many expect the federal government to come to the rescue with the correct plan of attack and have done it yesterday even though they don't want to pay taxes or have a big government. 2) We need oil for the near future and perhaps longer because we do not have the technology ready for an alternative. Because oil is needed and because oil companies need good PR they should form groups in each basin to develop and have ready viable back up plans, such as another rig near by to come in and plug the break. Each basin should have a site specific plan and the material close enough and ready to deploy in the event of a spill to prevent environmental disasters, not to mention the damage to the reservoir. They apparently do not have such plans in place and this could and should lead to regulations requiring the development of plans, money for the plans provided by the oil companies based on their rigs in the basin, and more oversight to reduce the chance this will happen again. We are all human so something like this will happen again.

Plenty of blame for everyone but Louisiana and Texas, which profit greatly from the presence of the oil industry, should be much more proactive about safety and environmental issues in their off shores; this is especially true when they have so much sea food industry to protect.

It has been about two weeks now since the oil spill outside the Gulf of Mexico has occurred and BP America has yet to contain the problem. Because of that, it has now reached the shores of New Orleans. My question is why hasn’t it been contained yet? If federal officials said it could’ve been contained earlier, why wasn’t every effort used to do so? Not only has the oil polluted our water, but it has also ruined the habitats of the vast marine life. This escalates further into the food that we eat. There will be a massive plateau of sales from the Gulf of Mexico regarding food.
The NCAA said that the spill has grown to 5,000 barrels a day. Imagine what that will do to gas prices now. BP should be held accountable for their mistake and not the public. The government needs to have the spill cleaned up without the private company, but still bill them for the cost. Not only is this spill taking animal lives; it is taking human lives with the explosion that happened two days after the spill. I don’t understand the carelessness that is going on with the federal government. It’s the same carelessness from the coalmine fiasco. These are non replaceable human lives were talking about. The oil companies should not have sole responsibilities over major spills like this. There has to be better monitoring from the government or it will not be able to respond quickly enough to such situations. No body should’ve ever waited this long before every resource was used.

As a Iranian expatriate living in Bay Area, I salute all non-Iranians through out the world who care and sympathize with the purely Iranian internal struggle for transforming the current goverment into one of liberal democracy which respects human rights, rule of law and free elections.

God bless you all.

The fastest way to put this film-maker's neck in a noose
is for the ayatollahs to get the idea he's buddy-buddy with the Hollywood crowd,
viewed by the aforementioned as *communists, junkies and perverts*.

You're known by the company you keep,
and Hollywood's hyper-inflated self-regard coupled with
their sickeningly sanctimonious declarations are not viewed
everywhere the way they are here.

Here they're viewed as "bold artists" speaking "truth to power".

Elsewhere they're viewed as pompous frauds who'd
*hang their mothers on a meat-hook* for a 3-picture deal.

Most of the Hollywood characters you referred to
would rate the rope themselves over there
---that they made their statement *here* and not in Tehran,
shows the quality of the "courage" they've got.

The ayatollahs *know* this, and proceed accordingly.

This is one form of American cultural imperialism put to right use.

How will it be received by the political faction that runs state security? And more importantly, by the Iranian middle class and bureaucrats?

Responding to Libertine #8 how did you possibly get from my request that the Times give us additional technical information about the spill to
"You are grossly underestimating the seriousness of what is happening and how very long we will have to deal with the aftermath" ?

On the contrary, I know this is a disaster and certainly hope it deters drilling off the coasts of Va and NC. Just wanted to understand it better. Thanks to those who did provide additional info.

PC, or, Mac based computers, along with HiDef cameras are what's driving this trend towards "digital journalist". Just as the first video minicams replaced the 16mm film crew; so will the cellphone camera and amateur videographer, replace network ENG crews.

The expectation, and, aesthetic value, once valued in network news operations will continue to decline commensurate with their market share. Only the high value targets will get the full network treatment.
